user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SelectMultiple:
```c
int32 OS_SelectMultiple(OS_FdSet *ReadSet, OS_FdSet *WriteSet, int32 msecs)
{
    int32 return_code;

    /*
     * Check parameters
     *
     * Note "ReadSet" and "WriteSet" are not checked, because in certain configurations they can be validly null.
     */

    /*
     * This does not currently increment any refcounts.
     * That means a file/socket can be closed while actively inside a
     * OS_SelectMultiple() call in another thread.
     */
    return_code = OS_SelectMultiple_Impl(ReadSet, WriteSet, msecs);

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_SelectMultiple:
int32 OS_SelectMultiple_Impl(OS_FdSet *ReadSet, OS_FdSet *WriteSet, int32 msecs)
{
    fd_set wr_set;
    fd_set rd_set;
    int    maxfd;
    int32  return_code;

    FD_ZERO(&rd_set);
    FD_ZERO(&wr_set);
    maxfd = -1;
    if (ReadSet != NULL)
    {
        return_code = OS_FdSet_ConvertIn_Impl(&maxfd, &rd_set, ReadSet);
        if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
        {
            return return_code;
        }
    }
    if (WriteSet != NULL)
    {
        return_code = OS_FdSet_ConvertIn_Impl(&maxfd, &wr_set, WriteSet);
        if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
        {
            return return_code;
        }
    }

    if (maxfd >= 0)
    {
        return_code = OS_DoSelect(maxfd, &rd_set, &wr_set, msecs);
    }
    else
    {
        /*
         * This return code will be used if the set(s) were
         * both empty/NULL or otherwise did not contain valid filehandles.
         */
        return_code = OS_ERR_INVALID_ID;
    }

    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        if (ReadSet != NULL)
        {
            OS_FdSet_ConvertOut_Impl(&rd_set, ReadSet);
        }
        if (WriteSet != NULL)
        {
            OS_FdSet_ConvertOut_Impl(&wr_set, WriteSet);
        }
    }

    return return_code;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No suspicious fragments found. In both OS_SelectMultiple and OS_SelectMultiple_Impl none of the formal parameters (ReadSet, WriteSet, msecs) are assigned to or otherwise modified as objects of automatic storage: there are no statements like ReadSet = ..., WriteSet = ..., or msecs = .... Pointer parameters are only tested for NULL and passed to helper functions (e.g. OS_FdSet_ConvertIn_Impl, OS_FdSet_ConvertOut_Impl, OS_DoSelect) which may modify the objects they point to — this is permitted by Rule 17.8. Therefore there are no code fragments that appear to violate the requirement that the pointer parameters themselves must not be modified.
